A horrified mum is demanding a toy gun activity centre improve its safety after an oil drum fell on her son, leaving him needing surgery. 
But bosses at Stockport Nerf Centre say the seven-year-old ignored warnings not to climb on the oil drums. 
Sousanne Walton, 36, from Failsworth, Oldham, says the heavy barrel broke her son Finley’s finger as he lay on the floor and missed his head ‘by inches’ at Stockport Nerf Centre, in Bredbury. 
Finley, seven, was taken to hospital where he had an operation on his snapped finger. Read More My 13-year-old son was violently beaten up by a gang who lured him to another school on Snapchat 
He is waiting to find out if he needs more surgery to insert wire into the injured digit. 
Sousanne claims he was told he could climb on netting around the barrels, but when he did so it came loose and the contents crashed down on him. Finley Walton, seven, shows his injured finger 
Darren Palmer, owner of the centre, says a safety talk before the games and highly visible signs inside make it very clear this is not allowed. 
Sousanne said: “I heard a loud crash and when I saw it was Finley doubled over in pain I was hysterical. Then his hand started swelling and deforming in front of my eyes. Read More Fraudster who plundered bank accounts of David Silva and Manuel Pellegrini was caught after ex-City boss had card declined at restaurant 
“It was absolutely shocking and I am disgusted that it happened. I’m just thankful my little boy is so brave, 
“He was told he could go on the netting, but even if he wasn’t children will be children so the centre needs to take responsibility for the drums being safe. Stockport Nerf Centre is in this mill building in Bredbury 
“They need to look at this seriously and take action. I don’t want this to happen to another child, it was very close to landing on Finley’s head, then it would have been a different story.” Read More Gemma Atkinson left squirming after being asked if she's been dating a footballer 
Sousanne, a bank worker from Failsworth, had taken Finley and his friend to the centre on Saturday, January 21. 
North West Ambulance Service confirmed it was called to the centre to reports of a seven-year-old with an injured hand but turned back when he found alternative transport to hospital. Inside Stockport Nerf Centre 
Nerf guns fire foam bullets and can be used for activities similar to paintballing for all ages. 
Mr Palmer said: “Before people go in there is a safety talk they must listen to explaining the rules, one of which is don’t climb on anything. 
“We always have marshals inside. He started climbing on a drum and was told to get down. Instead he jumped into the scenery taking the drum with him. 
“We have had 7,500 guests come in without incident, every guest is - on arrival - told to sit down and listen to the safety talk.” Like us on Facebook
